Award.AwardTitle: NSF NPGI Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2014
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds an NSF National Plant Genome Initiative Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2014. The fellowship supports a research and training plan in a host laboratory for the Fellow who also presents a plan to broaden participation in biology. The title of the research and training plan for this fellowship to Chad E. Niederhuth is "Epigenomic Engineering in Soybeans to Unlock Cryptic Genetic Variation" The host institution for the fellowship is the University of Georgia and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Robert J. Schmitz.

Genomes possess an additional layer of information found not in the underlying DNA sequence, but in the modification of cytosine residues by methylation. As DNA methylation is a mechanism of regulating gene expression, it sits at the boundary between genotype and phenotype. Variants in the methylation status, or epialleles, not only affect the phenotype, but can also be heritable, being stably inherited across multiple generations without alteration to the underlying DNA sequence. Together with the proteins that make up chromatin structure, DNA methylation is part of a code that has come to be called the epigenome. Unlocking the nature of this code and finding mechanisms to manipulate it will add additional tools for breeders to translate discovery to application towards improving plant health and production. Training objectives include plant genetics, DNA methylation, epigenomics, bioinformatics, and quantitative genetics. Broader impacts include the mentoring and training of students, including outreach programs to underrepresented groups. This will include local outreach and aiding in the development of new courses.

This research proposes to uncover the links between methylation and phenotypes by using a multipronged approach to disrupt DNA methylation in soybeans followed by identification of methylation variants through whole-genome bisulfite sequencing. As part of this work, novel experimental populations of soybean for mapping epigenetic quantitative trait loci associated with phenotypic variation will be developed. In addition, new methods of targeted epigenome engineering will be used to confirm these associations and enable the use of the epigenome for plant improvement.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Plants regulate their DNA through the epigenome. This consists of factors that interact with the DNA to define regions of tightly packaged and “silenced” DNA (heterochromatin) and regions of open and expressed DNA (euchromatin). One of these epigenomic factors is DNA methylation, which is the chemical addition of a methyl group to specific DNA base pairs. Differences between individuals in which areas of the genome are methylated or unmethylated can be associated with differences in how genes are expressed and ultimately differences in plant traits. These epigenomic differences could potentially be an additional source of variation for plant breeders and the improvement of crops.

The goal of this research was to develop methods of engineering or modifying epigenomes, specifically DNA methylation, to create and identify new epigenomic differences for crop improvement. To do this we used multiple approaches ranging from chemical modification, the creation of targeted mutations, to the creation of transgenic lines expressing novel DNA methylation pathways. Chemical-based approaches resulted in dramatic alterations to the methylome and re-expression of previously silenced genes, but was also limited by side-effects. In another approach, we attempted to mutate specific genes involved in the maintenance of DNA methylation, but were unable to identify heritably mutations in subsequent generations. As an alternative, a comparative epigenomics approach that looked at DNA methylation across species was used to identify target genes and sources of epigenomic diversity. Surprisingly, this revealed that certain plant species, including economically important ones such as Rice, Sorghum, and Maize, are missing a functional copy of the gene CMT2. This is a key gene involved in DNA methylation. By reintroducing CMT2, it was possible to dramatically alter DNA methylation in these species.

Methods and techniques for modifying epigenomes are still very new and to date have only found limited application in human and mammalian cells. This research sought to discover and apply methods of epigenome engineering in plants. Multiple approaches were used with varying success. Using comparative epigenomics novel methods of species-specific epigenome modification were discovered. Future research will be needed to refine and carry forward these methods into application.
